fullProgramDescription: The Cognitive Science Department at UC San Diego offers an interdisciplinary program that focuses on the study of mind and intelligence. The undergraduate major provides a comprehensive education in the core areas of cognitive science, including perception, attention, memory, language, problem-solving, and reasoning. Students can choose from various elective courses to explore their interests in cognitive science.
shortProgramDescription: The Cognitive Science B.S. program provides a comprehensive education in the study of mind and intelligence, focusing on the core areas of cognitive science.
classHighlights: The core courses for the Cognitive Science major include Introduction to Cognitive Science (COGS101A), Cognitive Science Methods (COGS101B), Cognitive Neuroscience (COGS107A), Cognition (COGS108A), and Statistics for Cognitive Science (COGS14A). These courses provide a foundation in the principles and methods of cognitive science.

Students are also required to take additional courses in cognitive science, including Perception (COGS107B), Language and Thought (COGS108B), and Cognitive Development (COGS108C). These courses allow students to explore specific topics in cognitive science in more depth.

The major also includes a range of elective courses that allow students to explore their interests in cognitive science. These electives include courses on topics such as artificial intelligence, human-computer interaction, and cognitive development.

Students can choose from a variety of upper-division courses, including COGS120, COGS130, COGS140, COGS150, COGS160, and COGS170, which cover topics such as cognitive modeling, cognitive neuroscience, and human factors.
The department also offers special topics and seminar courses that allow students to engage with current research and issues in cognitive science.
learningOutcomes: Understand the core principles and methods of cognitive science
Analyze and interpret data related to cognitive processes
Apply cognitive science theories and models to real-world problems
Evaluate the strengths and limitations of different cognitive science approaches
Communicate complex cognitive science concepts effectively
additionalInformation: The Cognitive Science major is highly flexible and allows students to tailor their coursework to their interests. Students are encouraged to participate in research and internships to gain practical experience in cognitive science.
